thread.title: Jimmie Johnson got burned by new NASCAR Chase rules
thread.title_full: Jimmie Johnson got burned by new NASCAR Chase rules

author: freep.com
title: Jimmie Johnson got burned by new NASCAR Chase rules
text:
MORE Jimmie Johnson's early exit from the Chase for the Sprint Cup Championship is shocking — to his fans, sponsors and Hendrick Motorsports.
It's akin to the New England Patriots losing in the first round of the NFL playoffs or the Red Wings missing the NHL postseason.
The six-time Cup champ's car — the No, 48 Chevy — broke an axle at Dover on Sunday and will miss being in the Contender group of the Chase starting with tonight's Charlotte Bank of America 500.
While 12 other drivers are eligible for the title, Johnson will run around between now and the championship-ending race at Homestead-Miami on Nov. 22 working on next year's program.
Sure, he could win races, and probably will at Charlotte just to prove a point.
But it won't help him to a record-tying seventh championship.
Not that Jimmie is crying on anyone's shoulder. Johnson has had incredible success at Hendrick, NASCAR's top team.
But it was achieved through hard work and consistency.
Johnson is the most dedicated driver in Hendrick's garage and deserves his trophies every year.
The title will be won by someone else this season, possibly for the first time by Team Penske's Joey Logano or Joe Gibbs Racing's Kyle Busch.
It will go down to the wire, no doubt, under the rules package.
But I'm not convinced NASCAR has it right with the Chase format.
Racing isn't baseball or hockey. Victories don't come in clumps.
Consider Johnson has four wins this season and is out of the Chase, while Jeff Gordon and Ryan Newman, winless in 2015, are still in contention.
The math doesn't add up.
I'll wager Jimmie feels the same, though he'll likely not complain.
I think NASCAR still must figure out a fairer way of rewarding postseason competition, or just go back to most points or wins throughout the entire season to crown a champion.
Contact Mike Brudenell: mbrudenell@freepress.com. @mikebrudenell.
This weekend's races
NASCAR Sprint Cup: Bank of America 500
On track: At Charlotte Motor Speedway, Concord, N.C.; 30th of 36 races.
On TV: 7 tonight on NBC (Channel 4 in Detroit).
Overview: Kevin Harvick is the defending champ and will be tough to toss again. Expect Carl Edwards, who won at Charlotte in May, to be right there at the finish along with Joey Logano, Kyle Busch and Jimmie Johnson, who has won seven times on the 1.5-mile oval.
Our picks: 1. Logano, 2. Busch, 3. Johnson.
NASCAR Xfinity Series: Drive for the Cure 300
On track: At Charlotte Motor Speedway; 29th of 34 races.
On TV: 8 p.m. today on NBC Sports Network.
Overview: Bryon's Erik Jones will drive the No. 20 car for Joe Gibbs Racing, while Cup regulars Kyle Busch, Kasey Kahne, Brad Keselowski and Austin Dillon will make starts.
Our picks: 1. Busch; 2. Keselowski; 3. Kahne.
Formula One: Russian Grand Prix
On track: At Sochi Autodrom, Sochi, Russia; 15th of 19 races.
On TV: 7 a.m. Sunday on NBC Sports Network.
Overview: Lewis Hamilton won in Russia last year and is dominating the 2015 season. But Nico Rosberg could rally to beat his Mercedes teammate.
Our picks: 1. Rosberg, 2. Hamilton, 3. Sebastian Vettel.
